statement.tex: \text{Find the second order derivative of the }\\ \text{function } x . \cos x.

step.context: \text{Is the following the correct way to }\\ \text{find } \dfrac{d^2{f(x)}}{dx^2}\text{ where $f(x) =x . \cos x$}?
step.tex: \text{First, finding the first order derivative}\\ \begin{align} \dfrac{d(f(x))}{dx} &= \dfrac{d(x .\cos x)}{dx}\\ &= \dfrac{d(x)}{dx} . \cos x + x . \dfrac{d(\cos x)}{dx}\\ &= \cos x - x . \sin x \end{align}\\ \text{Now, finding the second order derivative}\\ \begin{align} \dfrac{d^2(f (x))}{dx^2} &= \dfrac{d(f^{\prime}(x))}{dx}= \dfrac{d(\cos x - x . \sin x )}{dx}\\ &=\dfrac{d(\cos x)}{dx}- \dfrac{d(x .\sin x)}{dx}\\ &=- \sin x - \dfrac{d(x)}{dx}. \sin x - x . \dfrac{\sin x}{dx}\\ &=-sinx -\sin x - x .\cos x\\ &=- x \, \cos x - 2\sin x \end{align}
step.reason: \text{Other than Chain Rule we have used the fact}\\ \text{that }\frac{d(\sin \theta)}{d\theta}= \cos \theta \text{ and }\frac{d(\cos \theta)}{d\theta}= -\sin \theta
